Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

When it comes time to find a job, theyâ€™ll already know people in their field who can help them get a foot in the door.Affordable, High-Quality Education Unlike in the U.S., where university costs can be crushing, Israel offers world-class higher education at a fraction of the price. Many children of Olim attend university almost for free, thanks to government subsidies and scholarships. They can graduate without student debt, giving them a huge financial advantage.A Strong Social System Israelâ€™s healthcare system is among the best in the world and is accessible to all residents. There are also generous benefits for young families, including tax breaks, free daycare options, and social programs that make life easier as they start their own families.While you as a parent may experience some challenges, your children will grow up fully integrated, fluent in Hebrew, and part of a society that values community and support. Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Making Aliyah with Kids: An Investment in Their FutureMoving to Israel with children can feel overwhelming. As parents, you might worry about jobs, finances, or adjusting to a new culture. But while there may be struggles along the way, making Aliyah is one of the best investments you can make for your childrenâ€™s future.A Built-in Network for Success In Israel, connections (known as protektzia) play a huge role in finding jobs and opportunities. Children who grow up here naturally build friendships, attend school with future colleagues, and serve in the army or national service, forming bonds that last a lifetime. When it comes time to find a job, theyâ€™ll already know people in their field who can help them get a foot in the door.Affordable, High-Quality Education Unlike in the U.S., where university costs can be crushing, Israel offers world-class higher education at a fraction of the price. Many children of Olim attend university almost for free, thanks to government subsidies and scholarships. They can graduate without student debt, giving them a huge financial advantage.A Strong Social System Israelâ€™s healthcare system is among the best in the world and is accessible to all residents. There are also generous benefits for young families, including tax breaks, free daycare options, and social programs that make life easier as they start their own families.While you as a parent may experience some challenges, your children will grow up fully integrated, fluent in Hebrew, and part of a society that values community and support. The struggles you face now are temporary, but the benefits for your children will last a lifetime.Aliyah is more than a moveâ€”itâ€™s an investment in a brighter future for your family. And thatâ€™s worth everything.

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Children who grow up here naturally build friendships, attend school with future colleagues, and serve in the army or national service, forming bonds that last a lifetime. When it comes time to find a job, theyâ€™ll already know people in their field who can help them get a foot in the door.Affordable, High-Quality Education Unlike in the U.S., where university costs can be crushing, Israel offers world-class higher education at a fraction of the price. Many children of Olim attend university almost for free, thanks to government subsidies and scholarships. They can graduate without student debt, giving them a huge financial advantage.A Strong Social System Israelâ€™s healthcare system is among the best in the world and is accessible to all residents. There are also generous benefits for young families, including tax breaks, free daycare options, and social programs that make life easier as they start their own families.While you as a parent may experience some challenges, your children will grow up fully integrated, fluent in Hebrew, and part of a society that values community and support. The struggles you face now are temporary, but the benefits for your children will last a lifetime.Aliyah is more than a moveâ€”itâ€™s an investment in a brighter future for your family. Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? I keep having my comments removed but it's important to really bring home that Beyond the Streets, by default, conflate sex work and sexual exploitation. BtS see them as synonymous l(see comments for evidence) I thank Emily Vaughn for highlighting this, and repeatedly. Listen to SWers & not block or delete those voices that don't align with organisations.It's important when working with marginalised groups that they are able to access you and be supported to attend services. This includes beyond phone support in another city.Generally, why is the conflation considered dangerous?- Genuine victims of exploitation are seen as sex workers, which is inappropriate- Sex workers' autonomy and consent is decided for us and removed- Allows others (especially women) to speak over sex workers because they're seen as victims who are too traumatised and need someone to speak for "the voiceless"- Consent - the biggest difference- Ignores the boundaries set by the sex worker themselves- Sex workers not believed when genuinely exploited because it's seen as all the same - IF WE BELIEVE WHEN SOMEONE SAYS THEYRE RAPED, WE MUST BELIEVE IT WHEN THEY SAY THEY ARE NOT

Making Aliyah with Kids: An Investment in Their FutureMoving to Israel with children can feel overwhelming. As parents, you might worry about jobs, finances, or adjusting to a new culture. But while there may be struggles along the way, making Aliyah is one of the best investments you can make for your childrenâ€™s future.A Built-in Network for Success In Israel, connections (known as protektzia) play a huge role in finding jobs and opportunities. Children who grow up here naturally build friendships, attend school with future colleagues, and serve in the army or national service, forming bonds that last a lifetime. When it comes time to find a job, theyâ€™ll already know people in their field who can help them get a foot in the door.Affordable, High-Quality Education Unlike in the U.S., where university costs can be crushing, Israel offers world-class higher education at a fraction of the price. Many children of Olim attend university almost for free, thanks to government subsidies and scholarships. They can graduate without student debt, giving them a huge financial advantage.A Strong Social System Israelâ€™s healthcare system is among the best in the world and is accessible to all residents. There are also generous benefits for young families, including tax breaks, free daycare options, and social programs that make life easier as they start their own families.While you as a parent may experience some challenges, your children will grow up fully integrated, fluent in Hebrew, and part of a society that values community and support. The struggles you face now are temporary, but the benefits for your children will last a lifetime.Aliyah is more than a moveâ€”itâ€™s an investment in a brighter future for your family. And thatâ€™s worth everything.
